getty.ScopeNote: First mentioned in Tell al-ʻAmarna letters 1370 BCE; holy city of Jews, Christians and Muslims; viewed as international city by United Nations' partition of Palestine; after the 1948 war, the city was divided between Jordan and Israel; the entire city was claimed by Israel in 1967.

entity.second: Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd Allah al-Ghafiki

Alternativnamen.Name: Abd ar-Rahman ibn Abdallah al-Ghafiqi
König Abd ar-Rahman
Abd ar-Rahman
Abdul Rahman Al Ghafiqi
Adirama
Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd Allah al-Ghafiki

getty.ScopeNote: Site of ruined fortress that served as a Saracen base 890-973 CE.

Area inhabited by Neanderthals 20,000 BCE, Homo Sapiens 13,000 BCE; growth of Almería culture 3000 BCE, El Argar 2000 BCE, and Tartessus 1000 BCE; colonized by Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, and Visigoths; Muslim conquest in the 8th century; global expansion 15th-19th centurries; official language is Spanish, though Catalan, Galician, and Basque are also spoken.

Refers to the first North African territory of the Roman Empire, at times roughly corresponding to modern Tunisia; parts of modern northern Libya were included as well. It was acquired in 146 BCE after the destruction of Carthage at the end of the Third Punic War; it was a proconsular province by 133 BCE. Julius Caesar and the emperor Augustus founded 19 colonies here, with Colonia Julia Carthago rapidly becoming an important city. Augustus expanded the province by combining the original province of Africa Vetus ("Old Africa") with the province Caesar had designated as Africa Nova (New Africa"); Africa Nova was composed of the old kingdoms of Numidia and Mauretania. The province exported olive oil to Rome between the 1st and 4th centuries. The numerous and magnificent Roman ruins in Tunisia and Libya attest to the region's prosperity under Roman rule. The province of Numidia was created in the western end of Africa province in the late 2nd century CE under the emperor Septimius Severus; a century later Diocletian formed two provinces, Byzacena and Tripolitania, from the southern and eastern parts of the old province. Germanic Vandals invaded in the 5th century and the area went into decline; Arab invaders conquered the area in the 7th century.

The city was held by the Persian Empire in 512 BCE. Later was a Roman Republic free city. It was the seat of Constantine I's empire from 330, and the terminus of the ancient Silk Road trade route. Was declared a Christian city by Constantine. From the 6th-13th centuries, the city was attacked by Persians, Arabs, Bulgars and Russians, and eventually taken by the Fourth Crusade army in 1203. Later taken by Ottomans.

Carthaginian settlement was taken by Romans; Visigoths then held the city until Moorish rule began in 8th century CE; Carolingian supremacy began in 801; powerful medieval counts controlled all of Catalonia and Aragon; was great commercial power.

Area of ancient northwestern Africa, west of Numidia, corresponding to present northern Morocco and western and central Algeria north of the Atlas Mountains. Its native inhabitants, seminomadic pastoralists of Berber stock, were known to the Romans as the Mauri and the Massaesyli; Phoenicians and Carthaginians also settled along the coast from the 6th century BCE. From the late 2nd century BCE, the kings of Mauretania were Roman vassals. Annexed to Rome in 42 CE and divided into two provinces: Mauretania Tingitana, with its capital at Tingis, and Mauretania Caesariensis, with its capital at Caesarea. Invaded by Vandals in the 5th century CE; later taken by Muslim Arabs.

Captured by Vandals 526; taken by Byzantines 554; under Muslims by 903; conquest of Mallorca & Ibiza by James I of Aragón 1229-1235; fell to Alfonso III 1287; after independence under Aragón again 1349; British occupied Menorca 1713-1802.

Largely coextensive with the modern region of France. Island was inhabited in ancient times by Etruscans, Phoenicians, Phocaeans, and Carthaginians; went to Rome in the 3rd century BCE, to Vandals in the 5th century CE, then to Byzantines; later held by Goths, Franks, and Saracens; disputed by Pisa and Genoa from the 14th century. For the region of France having the same name, use "Corse (region (administrative division))."

Conquered by Romans 206 BCE; declined under rule of Visigoths 572-711; taken and almost completely ruined by Muslims 711; prospered as artistic and intellectual center in Middle Ages; annexed to Sevilla 1078; under control of Ferdinand III of Castile 1236.

Situated on S bank of Ebro river; one of earliest Spanish towns to be Christianized; fell to Germanic Suebi tribe, then to Visigoths 5th cen.; captured by Moors around 714; taken by Almoravids 1110; captured by King Alfonso I of Aragon 1118.

The city is located on a narrow strip of land between the Mediterranean Sea and Lake Mariut; it is now partially submerged. It was the center of Hellenic scholarship and science in antiquity. It was built by the Greek architect Dinocrates for Alexander the Great. It was the renowned capital of the Ptolemies when they ruled Egypt. It was noted for its library and a great lighthouse on the island of Pharos. It was captured by Caesar in 48 BCE, taken by Arabs in 640 and by Turks in 1517. The city was famed for being the site of convergence of Greek, Arab and Jewish ideas. It was occupied by the French 1798-1801, by the British in 1892; evacuated by the British in 1946.

Area of modern Egypt comprises the core of the ancient kingdom of Egypt; area was home to Neolithic cultures by 6000 BCE; Thinite dynasty united Upper and Lower Egypt ca. 3100 BCE; important Hellenistic center; part of Roman Empire until Arab conquest in 640, then Mameluk and Ottoman; official language is Arabic, though English and French are also widely spoken.

Large island comprising most of the Sicily administrative region of Italy. Home to Stone Age Sicani, Elymi and Siculi (arrived from toe of Italy ca. 1000 BCE). The island was colonized by Greece from the 8th century BCE and by the Romans by 215 BCE. It was later taken by Vandals, Goths (493 CE), Byzantines and Arabs (850) and it thrived under the Normans (from the 11th century) and the Hohenstaufens. The island formed a part of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies (or Naples) during the 12th and 13th centuries, and it was ruled by the Bourbons in the 18th century.

Îrān is located south of the Caspian Sea and north of the Persian Gulf. It borders Turkey, Iraq, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Turkmenistan, Pakistan and Afghanistan. The capital city is Tehran and the primary language is Farsi, although Turkish, Kurdish, and Afghan are spoken among the minorities. Islam is the primary religion. The country was inhabited in 100,000 BCE, but recorded history began with the Elmites in 3000 BCE. Three major dynasties of this pre-Islamic era are the Persian (550-331 BCE), the Parthian (250 BCE- 224 CE) and the Sassanian (224-651 CE). The Persians were able to establish an empire with the help of Cyrus the Great. This dynasty collapsed in 331 BCE when Alexander the Great conquered the region. After the fall of the Seleucid, Parthian, Bactrian, and Sassanian empires, the non-Persian Islamic princes began their rule. Following this period came the Safavid (1502-1736) dynasty (marking an Írānian state with roughly the same boundaries as present-day Írān) and the Qājār (1779-1921) dynasty. During Qājār rule, European intervention in Iranian politics began to elevate. After a famine and bankruptcy in 1921 the last of the Qājār kings, Nāser od-Dīn Shāh and Mozzaffar od-Dīn Shāh, set the grounds for Reza Khan's takeover, effectively beginning the last Persian dynasty, the Pahlavi (1921-1979 CE). Khan's son, Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi (1941-1979 CE), took power, and fled the country in 1979, giving way to the Islamic Republic of Írān.

Was a thriving ancient center on the Euphrates river. It was the capital of the empire of Hammurabi by the 18th century BCE; it was taken by Assyria in 690 BCE. It flourished under Nebuchadnezzar in the 6th century BCE; taken by Cyrus the Great in 538 BCE and by Alexander in 331 BCE. The city declined in the 3rd century BCE. Noted for the Ishtar Gate and the Hanging Gardens, which were one of Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and believed to be the source for the legendary Biblical Tower of Babel.

City positioned on 7 hills over the swampy Tiber river area; one of the oldest continuously occupied sites in Europe. Archaeological evidence attests to human occupation of the area from ca. 14,000 years ago, but the dense layer of later debris obscures Palaeolithic and Neolithic sites. Was an Etruscan city by 8th cen. BCE, their kings expelled and republic established by 500 BCE; soon ruled vast area and was center of Empire from 31 BCE; declined when capital moved to Constantinople in 330 CE; revived under popes.

Region in southwest France between Garonne and Rhône rivers, and Pyrenees and Cévennes mountain ranges; was Roman province by the 5th century; part of Visogoth Gaul and Spain; overrun by Muslims from Spain in 720; reconquered by Charlemagne in 759; part of Frankish empire.

wikidata.desc: governor of Egypt (646-656) and Navy head

meta.Rolle: Sohn des Emir Abd ar-Rahman I. von Cordoba

meta.Rolle: Elefant (Geschenk des Kalifen Harun al-Raschid an Kaiser Karl I., den Großen)

wikidata.desc: Elefant, Geschenk an Karl den Großen
Asian elephant given to Charlemagne by Harun al-Rashid

getty.ScopeNote: Large island coextensive with most of the modern Sardinia administrative region of Italy. Sardegna had a flourishing prehistoric culture, especially Nuraghi; settled by Phoenicians (800 BCE) and Carthaginians (500 BCE); was Roman from 238 BCE; taken by Vandals (455 CE), Goths, Byzantines, Popes, and Arabs; later went to Aragon (Spain), Austria, and Savoy.
State that grew up over time around the the Semitic Akkadian city of Babylon, from the period of the Akkadian Empire ca. 2300 BCE.

Ibin al Arabi

Ebilarbii

getty.ScopeNote: Region in southwest France between Garonne and Rhône rivers, and Pyrenees and Cévennes mountain ranges; was Roman province by the 5th century; part of Visogoth Gaul and Spain; overrun by Muslims from Spain in 720; reconquered by Charlemagne in 759; part of Frankish empire.

Home to Minaean and Sabaean kingdoms 1000 BCE; held by Assyrians, Hebrews, Romans, and Persians; home to Semitic tribes until Mohammed initiated consolidation 7th century; ruled by Mamelukes and Ottomans; resistance to Turks 18-19th centuries; modern states born 1930s.

Earliest inhabitants of the area were probably Natufians ca. 10,000 BCE; home to several great cultures, including Akkadians and Amorites 3rd-2nd millenia BCE; ruled by Alexander, Romans, Arabs, and Ottomans; shares name with ancient region covering a wider area; official language is Arabic.

wikidata.desc: Name im Tanach, dem Alten Testament und im Koran, Sohn Abrahams
Hebrew Prophet of Judaism, Christianity and Islam

getty.ScopeNote: Famed ancient city on Gulf of Tunis; center of powerful state that conquered Sardinia, Malta, and Balearic Islands in the 6th century BCE; battled Rome in 100-year Punic Wars; ruined by Rome in 146 BCE, but rebuilt as a Roman city; rebuilt by Vandals, ruined by Arabs in 698.

wikidata.desc: arabischer politischer Führer und Gründer des Islam
Arabian religious leader and the founder of Islam

getty.ScopeNote: One of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world; was ruled by Egyptians and Hittites until became independent Aramaean kingdom 1000-732 BCE; prominent in Hebrew history; included in many kingdoms until 661 CE; part of the ancient Silk Road; attacked during Crusades; occupied by British and Arabs 1918.

Jussef Ben Abd ur Rahman el Fehri

wikidata.desc: umayyadischer Statthalter von Narbonne in Septimania und moslemischer Statthalter von Al-Andalus

getty.ScopeNote: Area inhabited 100,000 BCE; farming and herding by 10,000 BCE; ruled by Hebrews, Egyptians, Persians, Romans, and Ottomans; shares name with kingdom existing 1025-933 BCE; much strife between Israel and neighbors since 1948; holds territory from the 1967 "Six Day War"; official languages are Hebrew and Arabic.

Inhabited since 50,000 BCE; settled by Indo-Europeans 1850 BCE, Etruscans 1600 BCE, and Greeks 800 BCE; united by Romans 270 BCE; independent states rose after fall of Holy Roman Empire, notably Naples, Milan, Florence, Venice and papacy; reunited in the 19th century; official language is Italian, though significant minorities speak German, French, and Slovene.

Settled in prehistoric times; was powerful Greek colonial area; taken by Romans in 268 BCE, by Byzantine Empire in 9th century CE, and by Normans in the 11th century; was center of Italian republicanism and united to Kingdom of Italy 1860.

A Greek colonial city founded in 706 BCE. Comprises old city on island and newer section on mainland. In the 8th century BCE, Greek settlers from Sparta and Laconia conquered the Messapian village of Taras on the Taras river and founded a new Taras on the peninsula (cut in 1480 by a canal) between the Mare Piccolo and the Mare Grande. Taras soon became one of the leading cities of Magna Graecia (Greek colonies in southern Italy), and its inhabitants founded several other coastal cities; fell to Romans 272 BCE; ruled by Goths, Lombards & Arabs 6th-10th cen.; part of Kingdom of Naples 16th-17th cen.; site of many Greek tombs & ruins.

Inhabited by Gallic people; part of Roman Cisalpine Gaul from 3rd century BCE; core of Germanic Lombard kingdom from 569; ruled by Charlemagne from 774, by bishops of Milan from the 11th century, by Visconti family and Sforza dukes 14th-15th centuries, then by Hapsburgs.

Frazione on the site of an ancient Etruscan site on the border between Etruria and Liguria, which gave its name to the district of Lunigiana. Contains remains of an elliptical Roman amphitheater dating to the 1st century CE. It destroyed by Saracens in 1016 CE. Luni was famous for its wine and marble quarries.

Area southwest of Pyrenees Mountains comprising Spain and Portugal; name probably derived from Iberus, Roman name for Ebro River; area settled in the south and east by Neolithic and Bronze Age immigrants from Africa and in north and central Spain by Celtic tribes from 8th-6th century BCE.
Refers to the kingdom of Charles the Bald, derived from a portion of the Carolingian Empire by the Treaty of Verdun in 843.

Historical and cultural region encompassing the southeastern French départements of Bouches-du-Rhône, Vaucluse, Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, and Var. It is roughly coextensive with the former province of Provence and with the present-day region of Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur. It was an important region for the Roman Empire; when the Roman Empire declined, the region was invaded by Visigoths, Burgundians, Ostrogoths, and Franks. It was part of Lothar I's realm in 843; it passed to Charles of Anjou as dowry in 1246; ruled by Angevins until 1481; ruled by Louis XI 1481. Invaded repeatedly 1524, 1536, 1704, and 1746 by rival French royalty.

Key defense point of upper Italy in Roman times; sacked by Attila 452; Charlemagne crowned King of Lombardy 774 and Frederick Barbarossa as King of Italy 1155; ruled by Visconti 1359 and Austrians, French & Spaniards 18th cen. until passed to nation 1859.

Was home to early Apulians and Greek colonists; came under control of republican Rome by 3rd century BCE; taken by Goths, Lombards and Byzantines; was duchy under Normans in 12th century; part of Kingdom of Two Sicilies and later of Holy Roman Empire.

meta.Name: Monte d'Argento
meta.Anmerkungen: Der Mons Garelianus liegt in der Nähe von Minturno (Lazio, Italien), ob es sich hierbei um den Monte d'Argento handelt ist nicht sicher.

getty.ScopeNote: The eastern provinces of the Roman Empire; particularly as established by Theodosius in 395 CE, a Christian empire that comprised the eastern half of the Roman Empire, which survived for 1000 years after western half crumbled into various feudal kingdoms; fell to Ottoman Turks in 1453; at the death of Justinian in 565 CE it included Asia Minor, Palestine, parts of North Africa, Greece, Italy, Sicily, Sardinia, Dalmatia, and southern Spain.

Founded 856 CE on site of ancient Casilinum; captured 1501 by Cesare Borgia; was one of the fortified defenses of the Kingdom of Naples; fell to Kingdom of Italy in 1860; scene of heavy fighting in World War II (October 1943).

Ancient city that was home to Umbrians and Etruscans; taken by Rome in 242 BCE; attacked by Hannibal (217 BCE), Marius and Sulla; flourished as key city on Roman Flaminian Way; given by Charlemagne to Pope in 8th cen.; destroyed by Frederick I in 1155, rebuilt; to Papacy 1354-1860.

Modern unitary multiparty republic with one legislative house. Official language is Greek, though English and French are also widely spoken. To refer specifically to the ancient confederation of Greece and its colonies, use "Greece (ancient)"; for historical Greece in general, use "Greece (historical)."

Settled in Neolithic period; center of Minoan culture from 3rd millenium. BCE; traded with Egypt of 12th Dynasty; produced great palaces and Linear A pictographic script; declined after huge earthquake and explosion of Thera ca. 1500 BCE; then ruled by Greece.

Nation's most important seaport; destroyed by Carthage 205 BCE and rebuilt by Romans; controlled successively by France, Milan, Austria, and Sardinia; ceded to unified Italy 1861; birthplace of Christopher Columbus (1447) and composer Niccolò Paganini (1784).
Refers to the kingdom of Louis II the German, derived from a portion of the Carolingian Empire by the Treaty of Verdun in 843.

Franken was one of the five major dukedoms of early medieval Germany, occupying an area now divided among what is now Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg, Rheinland-Palatinate, and Hesse. It was named after the Germanic tribe of the Franks, who settled it in the early 6th century CE, Claimed by the Merovingian dynasty in the early 8th century, it became part of the Frankish kingdom of Austrasia in the 9th century. Franken's dukes founded the Franconian (or Salian) line of German emperors. By the 13th century, its fragmentation into smaller principalities began. The name of the old duchy survives in the northwest section of Bavaria, in the names of the districts of Upper, Middle, and Lower Franken.

Area comprising modern Baden-Würtemmberg, Hesse and western Bavaria; originally settled by Suevi and Alemanni; taken by Franks in 5th century CE; powerful medieval duchy from 10th century; ruled by Hohenstaufen kings and emperors; bound in league of cities, 14-16th centuries.

Historic region that included a kingdom founded by Germanic people in the 5th century CE. It was conquered by the Merovingians and incorporated into the Frankish Empire in the 6th century. It was divided in the 9th century, and united as the Kingdom of Burgundy or Arles in 933. The area flourished culturally during the 14th-15th centuries.

Huge system of parallel ranges that separates Italian peninsula from rest of Europe; originally formed by collision of African and European tectonic plates; various passes through the mountains have historically been of strategic importance for trade and war.

Founded by Clovis I in late 5th cen.; greatly expanded by Charlemagne (assumed title of emperor in 800), who added the Lombard kingdom in Italy, subdued the Saxons, & annexed Bavaria; empire collapsed in mid-9th century & gave way to feudal duchy.

The modern region of Aquitaine is roughly coextensive with the western half of the historical region of the same name. It encompasses the départements of Dordogne, Gironde, Landes, Lot-et-Garonne, and Pyrénées-Atlantiques in southwestern France. Conquered by Franks in 507; it was a duchy until 768; made subkingdom by Charlemagne and given to his son Louis 781; to the French crown in 877. It became a powerful feudal duchy controlling most of France south of Loire by the 11th century. Passed to Capetians in 1137, to the English in 1152. An administrative division until 2016, when it was grouped with the Limousin and Poitou-Charentes regions to form the new region, "Nouvelle-Aquitaine."

Said to be first Roman colony beyond the Alps, founded in 118 BCE; taken by Visigoths in 412, by Saracens in 719 and by Pepin the Short in 759; flourished as manufacturing city 11th-12th centuries; boulevards replaced medieval fortifications by 1870; site of 11th- and 14th-century church.

Poitiers is located on high ground where the Clain and Boivre rivers meet. It takes its name from the sites first settlers, a Gallic tribe called the Pictones, or Pictavi. It became a Christian center in the 4th century. The Visigoths settled in Poitiers in the 5th century but the site was taken over in 507 by the Frankish king Clovis. Poitiers was one of the pilgrimage sites on route to the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela. Control of Poitiers alternated between France and England between the 12th and 14th century. The French heroine Saint Joan of Arc was interrogated there in 1429. Poitiers suffered severely during the 16th-century Wars of Religion. Parts of Poitiers were destroyed during World War II. It contains many ancient monuments dispersed throughout the town. The Notre-Dame-la-Grande church is an example of Romanesque architecture, with a 12th century facade containing many sculptures. Located in Poitiers is the 4th-century rectangular Baptistère Saint-Jean, which is estimated to be the oldest Christian edifice in France; it now houses an archaeological museum containing tombs dating from the 5th to the 8th century. There has been recent industrial growth in the area of printing, rubber, electrical machinery, and chemical industries.
